channel.title: Nobrega Lab on Home
channel.description: Recent content in Nobrega Lab on Home

item.title: Genetic Regulation of obesity and fat deposition
item.description: A central question in modern human genetics is how to identify the genes that are involved in human disease. This is a challenging topic, as most mutations that cause disease are located in non-coding regions of the genome. These mutations often act by disrupting gene regulators. Using a combination of statistical genetics and in vitro experiments, our lab identifies and characterizes genes that are involved in obesity, and defines the gene regulatory networks that control weight gain.

item.title: Epigenetic inheritance of metabolic health
item.description: Most heritability is caused by direct mutation to the genome of an organism. However, epigenetic changes to the genome, such as repression or activation of certain genes, can pass through the germ cells of an organism and affect their offspring. This kind of heritability, called epigenetic inheritance, may be particularly important. Our lab, together with the Barres Lab at the University of Copenhagen and the Simpson lab at the University of Sydney, comprise the GECKO consortium.

item.title: Genome architecture in disease
item.description: Recent research has revealed that DNA is in the nucleus in ways that control and direct gene expression. Topologically associating domains, or TADs, are sections of chromosomes that self-segregate. Gene regulators within the TADs regulate genes within the TADs, and often cannot access genes that are outside their TAD. Therefore, if the boundaries of a TAD are disrupted, there may be severe consequences for the expression of genes in neighboring TADs.

item.title: Genetic mechanisms of preterm birth
item.description: Like many human traits, premature birth is a combination of environmental risk factors and genetic predisposition. By examining the genetic risk factors associated with preterm birth, we can identify genes whose mis-regulated expression increases the risk that an invididual person will give birth prematurely. Our lab has generated gene expression data, epigenomic data, and chromatin interaction data from placental stromal cells. Using these data, we are identifying novel factors which maintain pregnancy.

item.title: Débora Sobreira, PhD
item.description: Publications: Sakabe N.J., Aneas I., Knoblauch K., Sobreira D.R., … & Nóbrega, M.A. (2020). Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth. Science Advances. https://doi.org/10.1038/s42003-020-01411-4 Helling, B.S., Sobreira, D.R., Hansen, G.T., … & Ober, C.A. (2020). Transcriptional and Chromatin Responses of Bronchial Epithelial Cells to RV are Altered in Asthma. Communications Biology. https://doi.org/10.1038/s42003-020-01411-4 Montefiori L.E., Sobreira D.R., Sakabe N.J., Aneas I., Joslin A.C., Hansen G.

item.title: Ivy Aneas, PhD
item.description: My research interests stem from several GWAS studies that have implicated noncoding single-nucleotide polymorphisms in the risk of common diseases. One of the major hypotheses that we pursue is that variation on these noncoding sequences can have an impact on phenotype by altering expression of nearby genes. In order to identify those potential functional non-coding regions, my projects seek to: understand how enhancers coordinate to determine a complex pattern of gene expression, understand the dynamics of gene regulation across time, space and in response to stimuli, and evaluate the functional impact of regulatory variation in phenotypic variation and human diseases.

item.title: Noboru Sakabe, PhD
item.description: Publications: Sakabe N.J., Aneas I., Knoblauch K., Sobreira D.R., … & Nóbrega, M.A. (2020). Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth. Science Advances. https://doi.org/10.1038/s42003-020-01411-4 Montefiori L.E., Sobreira D.R., Sakabe N.J., Aneas I., Joslin A.C., Hansen G.T., …& Nóbrega M.A. (2018) A promoter interaction map for cardiovascular disease genetics. eLife. https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.35788 Boogerd C.J., Zhu X., Aneas I., Sakabe N.J., Zhang L., Sobreira D.R., … & Nobrega M.

item.title: Grace Hansen
item.description: Grace Hansen is an MD/PhD student who joined the lab in 2016. She is interested in identifying gene regulatory networks act in different tissues to regulate human traits. In the Nobrega lab, she has focused on identifying gene regulatory networks that regulate adipocyte differentiation and are involved in fat deposition. In this project, she has identified a subset of Alu elements which regulate female waist-to-hip ratio, and a gene, SNX10, which is required for adipogenesis in females.
